keyTakeAways: The US government is attempting to deport Mahmoud Khalil, a legal permanent resident and Palestine solidarity activist, over his campus activism at Columbia University.
Khalil was detained in March 2025, missing the birth of his first child, and was released in June 2025 following a lower court's habeas corpus decision.

The Trump administration has invoked a foreign policy immigration law to target activists accused of supporting terrorism or spreading anti-Semitism, a move challenged as unconstitutional by civil rights groups like the ACLU.
The ACLU and legal experts argue that expressing political opinions, especially on Palestine, is not grounds for deportation, and that the government cannot criminalize speech.
The government claims Khalil concealed his work with UNRWA on visa and Green Card applications, which may be used to justify deportation.
A previous immigration judge ruled in favor of deportation, but Khalil's case is now being appealed to the Board of Immigration Appeals and potentially to a circuit court on constitutional grounds.
A separate federal judge ruled in September 2025 that the Trump administration’s broader crackdown on Palestine solidarity activists violated free speech protections under the First Amendment.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Mahmoud Khalil, a legal permanent resident and Palestine solidarity activist, was detained in March 2025 after activism at Columbia University, and later released in June 2025 by a federal district court in New Jersey on a habeas corpus petition. The Trump administration is attempting to deport him, citing foreign policy concerns, claiming he concealed work with UNRWA on immigration forms. Legal experts and the ACLU argue that such deportation efforts are unconstitutional, as they weaponize vague immigration laws to silence political speech. Khalil’s case, along with broader rulings, highlights a national conflict over whether political activism related to Palestine can be legally punished. The case is now being appealed through the Board of Immigration Appeals and may go to a circuit court on constitutional grounds. A separate federal judge recently ruled that the Trump administration’s crackdown on such activists violates free speech rights, reinforcing the significance of Khalil’s case as a test of free expression in the United States.
title: Lawyers urge US appeals court to uphold Mahmoud Khalil’s release order
